coredata.dc:title: Hybrid lithium salts regulated solid polymer electrolyte for high-temperature lithium metal battery
coredata.dc:creator: Zhang, Yu-Hang
Lu, Mei-Na
Li, Qian
Shi, Fa-Nian
coredata.dc:description:
Herein, a blending solid polymer electrolyte that composed of polyethylene oxide (PEO) and polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) was prepared by a simple solution-casting method, and the effect of different lithium salts on electrochemical performance at high operating temperature was studied. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM), X-ray diffraction (XRD) and differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) tests were performed to reveal the physical properties of obtained electrolytes, and electrochemical measurements demonstrate that a mixture of different Li salts with appropriate ratio in PEO/PVDF (1:1) shows a better property at 60 ​°C. The assembled LiFePO4||Li solid cells can reach a specific capacity of 160 mAh g−1 with an ionic conductivity of 9.12 ​× ​10−5 ​S ​cm−1. Contributed to the adopt of dual-salts, a high
t
Li +
value of 0.66 was obtained. It can be seen that the addition of rigid polymer into a soft matrix can effectively enhance the mechanical strength of solid polymer electrolytes to resist the dimensional loss at high temperature, and the mixture Li salts can improve the electrochemical properties. As a result, this work can provide a practical solution for assembly high safety solid Li metal battery for high temperature.

Hybrid lithium salts
Solid polymer batteries
High temperature

xocs:item-toc-entry.xocs:item-toc-section-title: Li|SPE interfacial stability monitor and determination of Li+-ions transference number
Cell performances of solid polymer batteries

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: Characterizations of prepared solid polymer electrolytes (SPEs). (a) XRD patterns of SPEs with different salts. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images of (b, c) single-salt and (d, e) dual-salts (7:3) PEO/PVDF SPEs. (f) Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) and (g) Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) curves of different samples.
Dimensional stability tests of different temperature.
(a) Arrhenius plots of PEO/PVDF SPEs with different Li salts ratio. (b, c) Linear fit of ln σ by VTF model with T 0 ​= ​−45 ​°C for both SPEs. (c) Electrochemical stability window of different SPEs.

Chronoamperometry test with a 10 ​mV ​d.c. Polarization for a symmetric Li||Li cell (Inset displays the impedance response before and after the d.c. polarization): (a) dual-salts (7:3) PEO/PVDF SPE and (b) single-salt (LiTFSI) PEO/PVDF SPE. (c) Interfacial resistance monitoring of dual-salts (7:3) PEO/PVDF SPE using a Li||Li symmetric cell. (d) The voltage profiles of Li||Li symmetric cells at different current density. All the measurements were carried out at 60 ​°C.

The performances of LiFePO4|SPE|Li cells tested at 60 ​°C: (a) Cycle performance (b) Rate performance (0.1C, 0.2C, 0.5C, 1 ​C and 0.1C); (c) The LED lights lightened by LiFePO4|SPE|Li cells; (d) Long-term cycling of dual-salts (7:3) PEO/PVDF SPE.
SEM images of LiFePO4|SPE|Li Cell after 100 cycles: (a) LiTFSI-PEO SPE; (b) dual-salts (7:3) PEO/PVDF SPE.

head.ce:title: Hybrid lithium salts regulated solid polymer electrolyte for high-temperature lithium metal battery

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: School of Environmental and Chemical Engineering, Shenyang University of Technology, Shenyang, 110087, China

sa:affiliation.sa:organization: School of Environmental and Chemical Engineering

ce:affiliation.ce:source-text: School of Environmental and Chemical Engineering, Shenyang University of Technology, Shenyang, 110087, China

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para:
Herein, a blending solid polymer electrolyte that composed of polyethylene oxide (PEO) and polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) was prepared by a simple solution-casting method, and the effect of different lithium salts on electrochemical performance at high operating temperature was studied. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM), X-ray diffraction (XRD) and differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) tests were performed to reveal the physical properties of obtained electrolytes, and electrochemical measurements demonstrate that a mixture of different Li salts with appropriate ratio in PEO/PVDF (1:1) shows a better property at 60 ​°C. The assembled LiFePO4||Li solid cells can reach a specific capacity of 160 mAh g−1 with an ionic conductivity of 9.12 ​× ​10−5 ​S ​cm−1. Contributed to the adopt of dual-salts, a high
t
Li +
value of 0.66 was obtained. It can be seen that the addition of rigid polymer into a soft matrix can effectively enhance the mechanical strength of solid polymer electrolytes to resist the dimensional loss at high temperature, and the mixture Li salts can improve the electrochemical properties. As a result, this work can provide a practical solution for assembly high safety solid Li metal battery for high temperature.

The PEO/PVDF blending polymer membrane shows a high dimensional stability at high temperature and the hybrid Li salts (LiTFSI/LiODFB) can improve the ionic conductivity of solid polymer electrolytes. The assembled solid polymer lithium battery shows an excellent cycling performance and an improved safety for solid polymer lithium batteries at 60 ​°C.
Image 1

ce:section.ce:para: High safety, high-energy density and long cycle-life are the key development targets for electric vehicle (EV) and hybrid electric vehicle (HEV) which are under urgent need in the research area [1–4]. However, the conflict of high performance and safety problem for traditional liquid electrolyte-based lithium-ion battery faces a dilemma due to the flammable carbonate organic solvent [5–8]. Furthermore, the Li dendrites formation during plating and stripping under electrochemical process will lead to short-circuit and even cause combustion and explosion, which restrict the application of optimal metallic lithium anode [9–11].

The adoption of solid state electrolytes instead of unstable liquid systems is considered to be an efficient strategy to solve the safety hazards mentioned above. In addition, batteries assembled with solid electrolytes can integrate the separator and electrolyte, thus simplify the configuration and manufacturing process of battery products. When associated with Li anode, a reasonable pack design will achieve further improvement of gravimetric and (or) volumetric energy density. The main three categories of solid state electrolytes that drawing great attention can be classified as inorganic solid electrolytes (ISEs), solid polymer electrolytes (SPEs) and inorganic/polymer hybrid solid electrolytes [12–20]. Generally, ISEs show higher ionic conductivity among all types of solid state electrolytes, some kinds of which even can be comparable with liquid electrolytes. However, the fragile nature of solid particles and large resistance at electrolyte/electrode interface of inorganic based electrolytes badly hinder their practical application. Recently, researchers have reported that the Li dendrites can grow along the grain boundary and eventually penetrate the ISEs, resulting in contact between electrodes [21]. Therefore, the aforementioned obstacles remain to be settled of inorganic electrolytes for applying in large-scale commercial manufacture.

At present, SPEs have received extensive attentions in development of solid state electrolytes [22]. Benefiting from the flexible polymer matrix, SPEs usually show good mechanical properties, interfacial wettability and electrochemical stability. However, restricted by their semi-crystalline feature, the mixture of polymer and Li salt always have intrinsic low ionic conductivity and moderate ion mobility at room temperature. Furthermore, the poor electrochemical stability under high operating potential constrains the assembly of SPEs with high-voltage cathode materials, leading to a limitation of battery energy density. Among various types of polymer matrix [23–25], polyethylene oxide (PEO) is the most studied system with optimistic overall performances and low cost, which has a high dielectric constant (ε ​≈ ​5) [26] for effective Li salts dissociation. Whereas, the inherent high glass transition temperature (T g) demonstrates a poor mobility of –CH2-CH2-O- segment under room temperature that reduces the migration of Li+-ions coupling with the movement of polymer chains. Cross-linking structure design [27] and plasticizers addition [28–30] are considered as effective strategies to reduce the crystallinity of polymers at room temperature. However, the mechanical strength and thermal stability of membranes would be deteriorated along with the enhancement of ionic conductivity. Moreover, the additives are generally fire-hazardous organics with short chains, leading to unsatisfied performances in practice.

Regarding the utilization at elevated temperature (generally ≥70 ​°C), the Li+-ions migration of SPEs can be accelerated due to the improved thermal motion of polymer segments. Therefore, high modulus and dimensional stability are more crucial for PEO-based membranes to ensure a long-term cycling. The complicated organic synthesis of copolymers [31], grafting polymers [32] and comb-branched polymers [33] are typical methods to increase the ionic conductivity, as well as the structural stability, for high-temperature SPEs. However, as for large-scale manufacture, a reliable system of PEO-based SPEs, which can be obtained through a simple and feasible approach are still under investigation.

Herein, a blending polymer system with hybrid Li salts for high-temperature utilization has been designed and obtained through a facile way, the differences between dual- and single-salt have been explored by physical characterizations and electrochemical tests. The aim for this work is to investigate the migration behavior of Li+-ions in a solid-state substrate at different temperatures, as well as the effect of different anions on electrochemical property. The results enlighten a promising perspective for dual-salts PEO/PVDF SPE to be applied for high temperature energy density and safe solid state lithium metal battery.

Poly(ethylene oxide) (PEO, M w ​= ​1,000,000 ​g/mol), acetonitrile (ACN, anhydrous grade, 99.8%), N-methylpyrrolidone (NMP, 99.9%) were purchased from Aladdin; Poly(vinylidene fluoride) (PVDF, M w ​= ​1,100,000 ​g/mol) were obtained from Alfa Aesar; Lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide (LiTFSI, extra dry) were bought from SOLVAY; Lithium borate difluoroxalate (LiODFB, ≥ 99%) were purchased from MACKLIN.

A homogeneous mixture was prepared by separately adding Li salt(s) and PEO (with a molar ratio of Li+:EO ​= ​1:20) into ACN solvent at 30 ​°C. PVDF was dissolved in NMP with a certain mass fraction and stirred at room temperature to get a transparent and viscous fluid. The solid polymer electrolytes (SPEs) were obtained by solution casting method after blending the above mixtures (with a mass ratio of PEO:PVDF ​= ​1:1). The solution casted on a polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) plate was then transferred into a vacuum oven and dried at 60 ​°C for 3 ​h and then heated to 90 ​°C for 12 ​h. After cooling down to room temperature, the solid membrane can be removed from PTFE and was stored in a dry atmosphere. The prepared SPEs are named as dual-salts (molar ratio) PEO/PVDF SPE and single-salt (LiTFSI) PEO/PVDF SPE, respectively.

The amorphous of different SPEs were initially discovered by X-ray diffraction (XRD) at a scan rate of 5 deg./min on a MiniFlex600 instrument (RIKEN, Japan), equipped with Cu-Kα radiation (λ ​= ​0.15405 ​nm) and operated at a voltage of 40 ​kV and a current of 15 ​mA. The surface morphology of SPEs was revealed by scanning electron microscope (SEM), conducted on Phenom ProX (Feiner, Netherlands). The glass transition temperature (T g) was confirmed by Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) measurement on Q20 (TA Instruments, USA) by first scanning down to −50 ​°C (i.e. cooling) and then to the contrary direction to 100 ​°C at a rate of 10 ​°C/min. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) tests were conducted on Q50 (TA Instruments, USA) in N2 with a heating rate of 10 ​°C/min.

SS|SPE|SS cells: symmetrical CR2032 ​cells were assembled of stainless-steel (SS) blocking electrodes and obtained SPEs (Φ ​= ​16 ​mm) in an Ar-filled glovebox (Univeral, Mikrouna, Co., Ltd, China). The electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was tested in a frequency range of 1 ​MHz–0.1 ​Hz at different temperature on a CHI660E (CHI, Shanghai Chenhua) electrochemical workstation.

The ionic conductivity σ can be calculated by equation (1) as following [34]:
(1)
σ =
l
R b
⋅ A
where
l
is the electrolyte film thickness,
R b
is the resistance of SPE, and
A
is the contact area between electrolyte and blocking electrodes.

Li|SPE|SS cells: asymmetrical CR2032 ​cells composed of SS cathode and Li anode were assembled to measure the ESW of SPEs. It was measured from OCV to 5.0 ​V by linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) with a scan rate of 1 ​mV ​s−1 on the CHI660E electrochemical workstation.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Li|SPE interfacial stability monitor and determination of Li+-ions transference number
ce:section.ce:para:
Li|SPEs|Li cells: symmetrical CR2032 ​cells fabricated by Li metal and SPEs were employed to check the interfacial stability during standing process. Moreover, the Li+-ions transference number was calculated according to the Bruce-Vincent-Evans equation (2), the Li+-ion transference number was calculated by combining the chronoamperometry and the EIS measurement before and after the chronoamperometry at 60 ​°C [35] using the Li||Li cells.
(2)
t
Li +
=
I s
( Δ V −
I 0
R 0
)
I 0
( Δ V −
I s
R s
)
The given ΔV is 10 ​mV, I 0 and I S are the onset and steady-state currents, respectively. R 0 and R S represent the interfacial impedances before and after polarization.

LFP|SPEs|Li cells: LiFePO4 (LFP), acetylene black and PVDF were mixed and ground by a weight ratio of 7:2:1. Afterward, drops of NMP were added as solvent to get a slurry and coated onto aluminum foil. The obtained electrode was dried at 90 ​°C for 12 ​h under vacuum. Finally, the CR2032-type LFP|SPEs|Li solid cells were assembled. All the tests of cells were conducted at 60 ​°C on a cell testing system (CT-4008T-mA, Neware Technology Limited., China) in a temperature test chamber (MGW-100, Neware Technology Limited., China). The LFP||Li cells were measured in the voltage range of 2.5–3.8 ​V.

The crystallinity of obtained solid polymer electrolytes (SPEs) was preliminarily revealed by X-ray diffraction (XRD). The XRD patterns of different membranes shown in Fig. 1 a both exhibit a low crystallinity of a broad peak at low degree range, which can be assigned to PEO and PVDF. This result implies a good amorphous of SPEs at room temperature, which can be attributed to the disordered arrangement of –CH2-CH2-O- (-EO-) chains because of the blending of PVDF. Furthermore, no peaks of Li salts were detected indicates a good dissociation of LiTFSI and LiODFB, and this can also make a contribution to restrain the crystallization of PEO and provide adequate Li+-ions for migration.

To investigate the micro morphology of SPEs, scanning electron microscope (SEM) was conducted and the images are shown in Fig. 1b-e. Compared with pure PEO-SPE, the surface of blending electrolytes is relatively rough and the homogenous rugged morphology suggests an amorphous feature of PEO/PVDF SPEs. No particle was detected on the surface indicates a well dissociation of Li salts in polymer matrix. Comparatively, the morphology of dual-salts (7:3) PEO/PVDF SPE exhibits a more disordered appearance than that of single-salt (LiTFSI) PEO/PVDF SPE.

On purpose to identify the thermodynamic property of prepared SPEs, differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) curves were tested and plotted. As shown in Fig. 1f, the DSC curves of both PEO/PVDF SPEs show an obvious endothermic process at low temperature range, which can be assigned to the glass transition temperature (T g). The detected T g indicates a semi-crystalline nature of both blending SPEs, and the T g values of obtained PEO-based SPEs are higher than that of pure LiTFSI-PEO SPE [36]. This result demonstrates a rigid chain property of SPEs after mixing with PVDF. During heat process, two absorption peaks related to the melting of blending matrix were tested. The first weak broad peak might be assigned to the melting of soft –CH2-CH2-O- segment of PEO, and the strong peak at about 47 ​°C is the melting point of crystalline PEO chain in SPEs. Compared with pure PEO, the melting point of PEO-based SPE shifts to lower temperature, which indicates that the polymer chains are disarranged by addition of Li salts and result in an increase of amorphous region. The coordination of –CH2-CH2-O- with Li+ can facilitate the motion of segments and lead to an acceleration of ionic conductivity. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) results are shown in Fig. 1g. The thermal stability of polymers after dissociating Li salts obviously decreases. Both samples show a weight loss of 1% before decomposition, which is the expulsion of H2O. The first main weight loss before 400 ​°C for dual-salts sample and 377 ​°C for single-salt PEO/PVDF SPE, respectively [37,38], can be attributed to the decomposition of PEO-Li+ complex and also the insoluble Li salts and anions. Whereafter, it is the thermolysis of PVDF. Comparatively, the thermal stability of dual-salts (7:3) PEO/PVDF SPE is higher than that of single-salt sample.

To evaluate the dimensional thermal stability of obtained membranes, a series of digital photos were taken at different temperatures. As shown in Fig. 2 , although the edge of dual-salts PEO/PVDF SPEs shrinks slightly, the shape and size maintain well even at a temperature up to 110 ​°C. However, the membrane with single salt shows a phase separation since 60 ​°C, and the appearance becomes semitransparent and heterogeneous. Nevertheless, it still can be removed from the testing substrate without melting. When the temperature rises to 80 ​°C, it starts to curl but keeps well in dimension. In contrast, the pure PEO-SPE melts and loses its shape at 60 ​°C, and its morphology changes irreversibly when the temperature returns to about 25 ​°C. The ultra-high heat resistance enlightens the application of PEO/PVDF SPEs in high-safety and high-temperature solid state batteries.

The ionic conductivity at different temperature was measured by electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS), and the Arrhenius plots of SPEs were plotted in Fig. 3 a. It can be clearly seen that the ionic conductivity values show different variation tendency at different temperature range. Above 50 ​°C, the σ values of all samples can satisfy the demand (≥0.1 ​mS/cm) of electrolytes to ensure the migration of Li+-ions. By comparison, the dual-salts (7:3) PEO/PVDF SPE exhibits a better performance below 50 ​°C, which can be attributed to the adoption of LiODFB that has a larger anion to enhance the formation of amorphous structure and result in an improvement of fractional free volume. However, with the increase amount of LiODFB, the ionic conductivity declines. This might because of the worse dissociation of LiODFB reduces active Li+-ions in electrolytes. Thus, the 7:3 ​M ratio of LiTFSI and LiODFB integrates adequate cations and amorphous area to provide a better transference matrix.

The activation energy E a of Li ​+ ​-ions movement can be calculated by the Vogel-Tamman-Fulcher (VTF) equation [39] (equation (3)).
(3)
σ = A
T
−
1 2
exp
[ −
E a
R
( T −
T 0
)
]
where A is the pre-factor that related to the number of charge carriers, E a is the apparent activation energy, R is the ideal gas constant and T 0 is the ideal glass transition temperature. In this work, we use the measured T g as T 0 to achieve the E a. By equation (3), the fitting result of E a value for dual-salts (7:3) PEO/PVDF SPE are 2.634 and 0.880 ​kJ ​mol−1 at high and low temperature range (Fig. 3b), respectively. Comparatively, the calculated E a value of single-salt (LiTFSI) PEO/PVDF SPE are 4.052 and 1.098 ​kJ ​mol−1 for high and low temperature (Fig. 3c). Smaller activation energy demonstrates an easier Li+-ions migration and more rapid ionic conduction.

Fig. 3d displays the electrochemical stability window (ESW) of different SPEs. For pristine LiTFSI-PEO SPE, the oxidative degradation potential occurs at round 3.8 ​V (vs. Li+/Li). After blending with PVDF, the ESW can be expanded to 4.3 ​V. The improved electrochemical stability can be contributed to the high voltage resistant –CH2-CF2- chain of PVDF. A potential shift to 4.5 ​V of PEO/PVDF SPE with dual salts might be due to the high-voltage tolerance of LiODFB [40]. The result of ESW measurement shows a high electrochemical safety for PEO/PVDF-based SPEs to operate with conventional electrode and even provide a development potential for high-voltage material.

As a low Li+ transference number (
t
Li +
) would lead to concentration gradient and cause large polarization between cathode and anode, resulting in dramatic capacity decay during cycling and even cause the growth of Li dendrite. Thus, a high
t
Li +
value is necessary to support the cell performance and the cycling security. In order to investigate the ion transport property of obtained SPEs,
t
Li +
were determined by a combination of chronoamperometry and EIS measurements (Fig. 4 a and b). According to equation (2), the calculated
t
Li +
of dual-salts (7:3) PEO/PVDF SPE and single-salt (LiTFSI) PEO/PVDF SPE are 0.66 and 0.53, respectively, both of which are much higher than that of organic solvent-based liquid electrolyte (∼0.36) [41]. The better ion transport property of solid electrolytes can be attributed to the transport mechanism of polymer and its poor mobility of chains, which can enable the directed migration of Li+-ions and constraint the movement of anions. Furthermore, the higher
t
Li +
value of dual-salts sample can be attributed to the larger size of ODFB− anion, which is harder to migrate during electrochemical process. The superior Li+ transference number of dual-salts (7:3) PEO/PVDF SPE can provide a basic condition to assure the transport of ions and reduce the polarization inside the cell. Moreover, it might be conducive to facilitate the homogeneous deposition of Li+ and suppress the growth of Li dendrite. As a result, the blending SPEs with different Li salts would afford an improved safety for Li metal batteries to operate under high temperature, owing to the high
t
Li +
of SPE, as well as the high thermal stability of LiODFB.

Li||Li symmetric cells were assembled to evaluate the stability of electrolyte/electrode interface by monitoring the impedance variation along with time under open circuit voltage at 60 ​°C. As displayed in Fig. 4c, the spectra show an incompletely semicircle at high frequency range (the inserted magnification graph) and a depressed semicircle in medium frequency region, which can be assigned to the resistance of the solid polymer electrolyte (R SPE) and the interfacial resistance at the electrolyte/electrode interface (R interface), respectively. It can be clearly seen that the resistance of SPE bulk reduces obviously after standing for a day under high temperature activation and it slightly changed afterward. The R interface dramatically drops during storage, which can be due to a wetting process between electrode and electrolyte. The decreased impedance indicates the formation of a favorable interface between SPE and Li anode.

In order to verify the behavior of Li+-ions, the stripping and plating measurement of non-blocking Li||Li cells at different current densities were conducted. A stable voltage profile and a low overpotential demonstrates a uniform current distribution and a small cell polarization. As shown in Fig. 4d, the overpotential of all samples grows as the current density increases, which indicates an enlarged polarization during electrochemical process. The pristine LiTFSI-PEO SPE exhibits the largest overpotential at 0.05 ​mA ​cm−2 with a flat and stable plateau. However, the cell shows a high polarization at 0.1 ​mA ​cm−2 and a short circuit occurs during cycling, which indicates a growth of lithium dendrite because of the unstable deposition of Li+-ions. The dissatisfactory performance of pure PEO SPE at high temperature can be due to the poor dimensional stability of PEO membrane. At high temperature, PEO keeps in a semi-molten condition and loses its mechanical strength to resist the growth of dendrite. By comparison, the PEO/PVDF blending system shows a higher stability at elevated temperature due to the mixture of PVDF with a higher melting point, the reversible process of Li+ depositing and stripping maintains well within a few hundred hours for both PEO/PVDF SPEs. The differences between single- and dual-salts at low current densities indicate a smaller polarization for single LiTFSI sample. However, the increasing overpotential of LiTFSI-PEO/PVDF SPE along with cycling implies an irreversible deterioration inside the cell. As for dual-salts SPE, the decreasing overpotential after cycling at high current density demonstrates an improved electrochemical performance after activated process and it can be maintained without any variations in 800 ​h. The result shows that an appropriate salt of high dissociation can provide more ions to migration at low current density. However, large polarization will happen due to the limited transference speed in polymer-based matrix. In this situation, anions with large volume can effectively reduce the concentration polarization and provide better rate performance.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Cell performances of solid polymer batteries
ce:section.ce:para: LiFePO4|SPE|Li cells were assembled to test the high temperature cell performance. As shown in Fig. 5 a, the unstable capacity and low coulombic efficiency of pure PEO SPE during cycling can be due to the poor mechanical strength, which might lead to uneven transference behavior of lithium ions and also worsen the contact at electrode/electrolyte interface. By contrast, the PEO/PVDF blending SPEs show better cycling performances with higher specific capacity and retention within 100 cycles. The increased capacity during cycling of both SPEs indicates an activated process for polymer segments to provide fast paths for Li+-ions migration. Relatively, the achieved specific capacity of dual-salts (7:3) PEO/PVDF SPE can reach 160 mAh·g−1. For rate tests displayed in Fig. 5b, the PEO/PVDF SPE composed of different salts exhibits higher capacity at each rate, which can be attributed to the larger volume of ODFB− that can increase the amount of valid Li+-ions and facilitate the movement of cations. In order to check its application in devices for power supply, a series connection with three coin-type cells were adopted to illume a LED light source (9 ​V DC). After charging, the cells can easily drive the LEDs to operate at 60 ​°C (Fig. 5c). The long-term cycling stability of dual-salts (7:3) PEO/PVDF SPE tested at 0.5C exhibits a capacity retention of 82% within 330 cycles, though a continuous capacity recession occurs. The average capacity is 126 mAh·g−1, which is acceptable for a solid cell for high temperature.

In order to examine the interfacial changes of each component inside the cell during electrochemical process, the batteries were disassembled after cycling. During electrochemical process at high temperature condition, the amorphous region of polymer increases to offer a better atmosphere for Li+-ions to migration. Moreover, the melting of PEO can improve the wetting of electrode/electrolyte interface, thus a reduced interfacial resistance can be obtained. However, in Fig. 6 a, it can be clearly seen that the pristine LiTFSI-PEO SPE becomes inhomogeneous after cycling for 100 cycles. The formed voids and holes between Li anode and LFP cathode will lead to the contact lost and even cause the short-circuit and security hazard. In contrast, with the existence of rigid PVDF, the SPE can retain its dimensional stability and ensure a long-term cycling at high temperature. As a result, the blending system can provide a prospect for high safety and high temperature solid Li metal batteries.

In this work, solid polymer electrolytes composed by blending polymers with PEO and PVDF were prepared through a feasible process, which can be applied for large-scale production. The mechanical stability with temperature were measured and the effects of Li salts on ionic conductivity, Li+-ions transference number, electrochemical stability window and cell performance were investigated. It was found that a mixture of different polymers can notably improve the high-temperature deformation resistance, and the adoption of dual-salts can enhance the lithium migration in a solid-state substrate. As a result, a mixture Li salts of LiTFSI and LiODFB in PEO/PVDF blending matrix shows a high ionic conductivity of 9.12 ​× ​10−5 ​S ​cm−1 and a lithium transference number of 0.66 ​at 60 ​°C. The discharge specific capacity of LiFePO4||Li cell can reach 160 mAh·g−1 at 0.1C (60 ​°C). The existence of PVDF can maintain the shape of membrane and avoid short circuit, thus improving the safety of cells that operated at high-temperature. LiTFSI has an excellent electrochemical property to ensure the amount of active Li+-ions. The adoption of LiODFB, which has a large anion, can decrease the polarization at high current densities. The above advantages make the dual-salts PEO/PVDF SPE a promising choice for high temperature solid polymer battery.

Yu-Hang Zhang: Conceptualization, Methodology, Writing – review & editing, Project administration, Funding acquisition. Mei-Na Lu: Validation, Investigation, Software, Data curation, Writing – original draft, Visualization. Qian Li: Formal analysis, Software. Fa-Nian Shi: Resources, Supervision.

ce:conflict-of-interest.ce:para: The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.
